TL;DR Released from Early Access way too early. Features and mechanics are not fleshed out, game decisions rarely matter and seem completely random, probably due to lack of any type of visual feedback which is crucial in this type of game. Great idea, but poor execution.The Idea of the game is pretty solid. The game is split into two parts, the first you get to take control of an amatuer gamer and turn them into a pro either at FOBA (the game's version of MOBA) or FPS. The second part involves leaving your old life behind and managing a team instead.I'm gonna break down into pro's and con's for easier reading :-Pro's Very unique idea Turn-Based, the game uses an energy system that allows you to make a number of actions each day. (Can be seen as a con too, but I prefer turn-based for this type of game) Ability to stream to make money Runs on most toastersCon's Lack of feedback from most aspects of the game. This is the biggest problem with the game that has been mentioned countless times to the devs but yet nothing has been done about it. Too random. This is somewhat tied in with the point above but outcomes of matches/tournements seem totally random, even if a similar strategy is used. This makes the game extremely tedious as you have no idea why the outcome is how it is. Stats, research, champ choices in FOBA and weapon choices in FPS don't seem to matter. While they did add some features that the community asked for, they didn't flesh out most of it out and it just feels tacked on. Gear is a great example of this, all this does is give you a passive stat once you reach certain conditions (basically achievements). Could have easily have made a PC shop that gave us the choice on what parts to purchase to increase certain stats or what not. Moving into new, more expensive houses, have zero benefit whatsoever.The game came out of Early Access WAY too early. Unless you want a very casual, randomized clicker I would stay clear of this game until they flesh it out properly.UpdateSo it has been nearly a month since release and the game is still in Build 175, I'd just like to point out that this was the lastest build back in the 19th of April, a week prior to release. The fact that we had no new build on release, no patches whatsoever post-release and no sign of the devs in response to any of the feedback since then, leads me to believe this game will no longer be supported. :(

								At this stage, PGM just can't be recommended. I honestly think it was released to Early Access too early.The core concept: A single gamer growing through the rankings, creating a team and eventually winning at the highest level is a fun idea... But everything beyond that seems to be mired in bad design choices.I know, that sounds unfair... but let's examine the first few minutes of gameplay.Alright, I've started a game. Oh, hey, my player has been randomly generated. Name, appearance and nationality. Well, that's okay. At least I got a name I can pronounce. Okay, so we play FOBA? We FOBA player now.Huh, this pick/ban phase is a little strange. There are three bans between two teams, and the layout makes it impossible to ban out AD champions. Huh. I guess that'll make more sense later on, when I start running the pick/ban phase myself.Wow, these champions look a bit silly. Still, that's understandable, it'd take far too much effort to come up with a ton of unique champions. Hell, they're probably randomised too. Everything else seems to be so far.Alright, I lost the game. It's okay, everyone loses their first game. Especially when they have to play support. But still, I'd like to know more about those champions...Wait, where's the champion info page?I think you can see where this is going... And it doesn't get any better. Nothing about FOBA is explained. All I can assume is that we're supposed to guess at how the game it played based on our pre-existing knowledge of MOBAs. Which is reasonable for a player like me, right?What, for instance, is the difference between a Chaser and an Initiator, or a Soaker and a Protector? What do these choices do to alter the game? NOTHING is explained about the results of your games, either in the soloqueue stage or in the later team stages.Ah. The team stages. Okay, bear with me, this is gonna get a bit meta.Pro Gamer Manager is realistic.No, really. In PGM, during what I'll call the 'bedroom' stage, you can choose to NOT play FOBA, and instead play one of three alternate games for stream potential. (FPS, Troll and Minecraft respectively). This will award you quite impressive amounts of money from your fans.You don't get money from streaming FOBA. Apparently MOBA players are stingy.And the best part? You can rack up way over a thousand credits in a single day while streaming, whereas you get virtually nothing from participating in the team stages... Hell, setting up advertising revenue or an eshop can result in tiny amounts of money.So an HOUR of streaming can net you 300 credits with 500 fans via donations and subscriptions... But a shop where you can buy stuff with that same money, and have it go to the same place? That generates 100 credits a WEEK with a thousand fans. And this is at the stage where you can no longer stream for some bizzare, non-existant reason, thus cutting off your only reliable source of credits!The funny thing is, that sounds realistic. A lot of the popular streamers (IE: The ones making the serious bank) AREN'T esports professionals.So... The moral of Pro Gamer Manager is... Don't be a Pro Gamer? Just stream. Then you won't go bankrupt.This game needs so much redesigning is a little bit sad. Here's hoping Early Access works. I'd quite like a good game based around this concept.

Pro Gamer Manager attempts to simulate the experience of, well, being a pro gamer. Watch streams, hone your skills, ascend the ranks, join a team, get a sponsor, and be the best gamer you can be. That's the idea, anyway: the game doesn't quite work out like that.


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



In Pro Game Manager, you’re given the option to play through one of two careers: Gamer and Manager. You are locked into whatever you choose and can’t experience another path unless you start a whole new game.Choosing either does nothing to change the storyline, as there isn't one, or the core gameplay mechanics, but it does affect the tasks you can undertake in game.From there, you can choose from one of two games: MOBA and FPS. The former is called ‘Foba’ for whatever reason, though I’m pretty sure the genre isn’t copyrighted. Nomenclature aside, your game type won’t significantly change gameplay: in fact, none decisions you seem to really affect anything, I’ve found.Upon starting as game, you are thrown into a room which, though nicely illustrated with simple but colorful components offer you no explanation as to how to proceed. Right clicking brings up a menu with possible actions, but it’s a matter of trial and effort to figure out just how each will affect you or, if you’re a manager, your team.As a gamer, you have the option to…Play Ranked: You choose how you want to build your player for the match and wait for the timer to count down to find out if you win or lose.Watch Stream: Raise knowledge by watching streams. I found that after a point (and without explanation) watching streams did nothing for me.Go to Bed: Rest until the next day. The energy bar is the more managerial thing you'll be doing that actually makes sense and has cause and effect.Research: Use EP to specialize your playstyleProfile: Allocate points to skills you want to strengthen. There's no telling what these skills actually do, so allocate at will.Gear: Use money to buy computer gear to play better and make more fans.Career: See your rank and how you stack up next to other players.House: Use money to buy a house once you’ve accumulated enough, which will allow you to have more team options.. When you start, you live with your parents.e-Sport Central: Attempt to raise your rank.Stream: Stream your gaming sessions to gain fans. This is not immediately available.Managing a team is slightly more involved in terms of matches due to the fact that you can click between three play styles - defensive, balanced, and offensive - but much like everything else, there’s not enough feedback to be able to tell how much this is affecting your chances of winning. I won't list the options available simply because they don't seem to correlate.That aside, there’s not much else to do in Pro Gamer Manager. Every action boils down to watching a timer tick down and that swiftly becomes tedious.The art style is simple and clean and works well. It would have been nice if there had been more than static images.The music consists of one looping track that swiftly becomes maddening when coupled with watching the timer circle fill..Pro & Cons.+As someone who’s played MOBAs, it was mildly interesting to pick from the list of available champions and specialize in a position.+Somewhat accurate representation of the tug-of-war struggle climbing the ranks can be.-Inflexible class, career, and game selection. If you want to try anything other than what you first picked, you'll have to start an entirely different game.-No tool tips or explanations of how stats function: Numbers and actions don’t feel like they have any weight. Stats and decisions don't seem to make any difference in a RNG dominated universe.-Gameplay oversimplified to a series of timers.-No explanations. Ever. If you aren’t already familiar with the two game types available, you’ll be lost.-No reward for experimenting characters approaches. Once you find what works, do it over and over again. "What works" is often stumbled upon by accident and doesn't seem to correspond with stats or gameplay decisions.-Lack of immersion due to the issues listed above..Bottom line.Pro Gamer Manager is a good idea that was poorly executed. It would take one small change to change this negative recommendation: if stats and decisions seemed to make a difference or even if battle outcomes were decided by a dice roll or rock-paper-scissors, this would feel more like a simulation game and less like a waiting game.If this review helped you, please give it a thumbs-up. 												Possibly one of the worst games available on Steam, this turd is laughably bad, even when you strip away the notion that it "could have been good."When I first got this game, I thought it was conceptually awesome. I'm a big fan of eSports just as a sport and following the LCS in LoL makes me substantially happier than playing the game. So I was willing to put up with a completely unfinished alpha build of a game.This game is full of placeholders. Almost every graphic, nearly every menu, every instance and event is clearly a placeholder. There is only one animation on the MOBA side of things, a spinning circle that is meaningless. Everything else is just stills and moving from one still to another. That's fine, Game Dev Tycoon is fairly light on animation, though at least in that game the screen does have movement. Everything in this game may as well just be text based because the images lend nothing to the game. I would have given a pass on the placeholders when I first got the game because there were updates almost weekly, and you got a sense that somebody was clearly developing it still. There were comical gaps, sections that were just plain empty, enormous bugs, and spelling errors everywhere ("Silly season is over" meant to be "Offseason is over" or the spelling of "Okey"). I assumed this thing was being thrown together by a couple guys in Sweden, and so I'll give them benefit of the doubt, they'll get this eventually I'm sure...Well here we are. The product on the MOBA side has released zero updates in over 6 months, and the FPS side, which I never played, is apparently a train wreck that I'm terrified to go near. I know a lot of people are complaining that the newest "update," which was supposed to be the patch to finish the game months ago and was so bad it needed to be immediately rolled back, has been announced as a DLC which will eventually cost money. That is certainly a horrendous and despicable decision, but I don't think reviews should even be upset at that; they should be busy losing their minds that the game is out of Early Access and still is nowhere near even a beta-level of release.Here are some bugs, just on the MOBA side, just off the top of my head:You have a 50/50 chance of a spelling error in any given message.Using the "Update free agent" staff member in MOBA Owner mode will cause the menu to no longer be available and erase your B team, not that you have any control over that team or input, and you must quit and reload to fix this.If you rank up in Career mode and are in the top 100 or so, you will over rank and get a ranking like -74.You will get notifications in your inbox but the email will be blank.No matter what league you're in, you won't be able to view the roster of at least one of the teams. It will always show another teams' roster.Players in owner mode can still skill up after hitting 99 and will show having skill points to spend, even though they can't be spent.If multiple players choose not to re-sign with your team on the same day, only one of them will show up in free agency.Let's also remember this: the game is stateless. That's right, a sports simulation game that is stateless, figure that out. There are no divisions above and below you until you move into that division. If you make it to the pro division in MOBA owner mode, you will always see the same teams. If you get relegated then return to the league, you will see those same teams again and players. This is especially fun if you picked up one of the players from one of those teams as now two of them will exist.If you drop a player into free agency, their age, nationality, rank, face avatar, name, and even role can/will change. Players also never age because the game has no general state. How long is a season? I don't know. All you can do is go to the next day and then if you do you can play a new match. After you play every team twice, the season is considered over, top 2 teams get promoted, and then it starts over again. There's no timeline, no real offseason (sometimes it lasts 2 days, sometimes 3, sometimes 4), and no schedule.For fun, here's a list of things you cannot do in, I will remind everyone, a game that is supposed to be a sports simulator:Trade players with other teams.Negotiate contract salaries with free agents.Negotiate contract term length with free agents.Negotiate contract term or salary when re-signing a player.Have more than the exact number of starting players (5).See the different leagues you can/will move between while not in them.Skip simulation of games or simulate an entire season (you must "play" every game).You only get one-shot with a free agent; if you accept their offer they may still just sign with another team with no chance for you to make a counter offer.Look at a calendar with all upcoming matches.Participate in play-offs or a championship.That's embarassing. There are plenty more I would put on the list but technically can't. They're listed as being in the game but don't actually do anything. For example, you can set up what the team does in their practice time by just clicking one of three options. It doesn't mean they'll improve in those skills because those aren't skills they can even improve in. You can also select a strategy for your "meta" but you can't see them execute the strategy, you don't know your opponent's strategy or style, you have no information on them, and it also has no impact. You can even decide what style each individual player should take up but again, it will not impact the results in any way.When matches are being played, here's what will happen. The game will give each team an overall score based on the five players skill level (1-99). And before you ask, yes every player can just get to 99, nobody caps out, nobody specializes, they just generically reach 99. It will then "draft" a team comp, which is you watching with no input on what is picked, not that you would know what any champion does or is because there are no descriptions for them. Pause review: there are no descriptions of anything in the game, nor any tutorials. Zero. After the draft it will tell you some meaingless sentence at the bottom like "GlassCannon Comp" or "HighMobility Comp." Again, these aren't described, you don't see anything play out, they don't mean anything. Your team won't have mastery over certain comps, so it may as well just say nothing. Then you enter a new screen with just the two teams on either side. You have three options: "Defensive, Balanced, Offensive" and guess what, none of them do anything. They aren't related to your comp, or your players' strengths, they don't change anything. All that matters were those numbers at the start. If you get an all 99 team, which you inevitably always will, you will always win every league game, with the odd rare exception to I guess make it look like a random number generator. But that's it.Except the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ international trounaments. I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ happened with these because they're the part that makes me actually vehemetly angry. The rest of the game I shrug and say "sure it's a piece of crap that doesn't do anything but at least it's numbers sort of make sense, even if arbitrary and meaningless and random. Team of 99s should always win, more or less."HaI welcome you to hell then. Try an international tournament. Put in your team of all 99s. Guess what? It doesn't mean jack crap. I swear to god they are an intentional joke meant to test your patience. It's like the developers knew they were making a ♥♥♥♥ game that doesn't do anything, but they also knew people would play it, so they wanted to test how far they could push us idiots who go early access on nothing but a concept by creating this wasteland of a game mode. It's completely random and meaningless even if you win.So no, I would never recommend this. It's not a completed game and they're not trying to change that.

UPDATE FOR FULL RELEASEThe game is now out of Early Access. Prematurely, as you'll find out.Many of the points below - written for an early version of the game - still stand.There is little to no feedback, not even to mention explanation. If you are not aware of the terminology in League of Legends or Counter-Strike, you will have a hard time understanding without researching it yourself.The game is a big grind for stats which ultimatively do not seem to matter. The results (winning, losing, stats) seem incredibly random, even if your team is half of the world top 10 players.I had a lot of hope for the game when it was in Early Access. I do think this was released way too early and the premature release hurt the game in the end.If you find this review unhelpful, I invite you to tell me why in the comments. Will do my best to explain my verdict and would happily take feedback.##################################################Original Early Access review below: ##################################################I was thinking about giving this the thumbs up or not. I decided that I should go by what the game is right now, not what it can be, promised to be nor I hope it turns out to be. The game shows a lot of promise but what's in there right now has too little long time motivation for me to recommend it. (the ammount of hours played is a bit skewed in my case as I left the game open for a night and work day).The game assumes you know a lot of terminology of League of Legends (since that is what the game is mainly taylored towards right now) and doesn't explain any of it.I've played a bit of MOBAs but never heard of an ADC in my life, because I haven't played LoL. Friends with multiple hundres (sometimes thousands) of hours of playtime in DOTA 2 and Heroes of the Storm didn't know either.The game generally doesn't explain itself too well right now. There is no tutorial yet and your performance in the game is not explained. You select a role (Top Lane, Mid Lane, Jungler, Support, ADC) and a chamption according to your role. There are types for champions (e.g. Sustain, Healer, Chaser, Utility, Tank, etc) but they are not explained. There are mutliple champions for each type but you are not told what differs Healer 1 from Healer 2, except for the "Tier" it is listed in, ranging from "SS" as overpowered champions to "C" as competetively non-viable champions - though it is not explained why. This tier list changes with patches to the ingame game which is a really nice mechanic in itself.Selecting a hero oddly enough also takes place before champions are banned (in MOBAs you often have the chance to ban a champion for a game so the other team can not use it), so you can take whatever champion you want.A Win or Loss also does not seem to take your stats into account. Of course, a single player seldomly carries a whole team to the win but my almost maxed out stats didn't seem to have any impact on the outcome of the game. You are simply not told what you've done wrong nor right.In order to increase your stats you can watch top players streaming the game, though Pro Gamer Manager doesn't tell you what you're learning. It doesn't tell you what stats increased, if you've learned something about playing a certain champion, etc. Different compositions of a team make up different strategies that range from a "Glasscannon", "FullAD", "NoInitiation", and "Balanced" to "NoDisengage", "Early Game" and others. None of them are explained so the player is expected to know about them, when they are not self-explanatory.After the banning phase (you take no participation in because you already have your hero selected) you chose a focus for Lanephase and Teamfights as well as a general Mentality. No explanation on what does what, as it is expected of the player to know. Your selected champion also has no impact on this, so you'll have the same strats availablle for a Healer as for a Sustainer.Game done, you're rated with a GameScore between 1 (worst) and 10 (best) and can see your Kills, Deaths, and Assists stats. Besides that and telling you if you've won or lost, there is no explanation. You can't watch your own demos in order to examine what went wrong either.The next game you might win, you will still not know what changed the outcome. I'm a fan of "eSports" so I've sunken quite some hours into the game and still enjoyed myself. Ultimately, it was just grinding and looking at a circle fill up and percentages increasing, since there is very little going on visually. There are a lots of areas that need a redesign and lots of bugs that need to be squashed. Having your own team doesn't seem to work too well and cuts you off from areas of the game (improving certain heroes, researching, streaming) for some reason. You also will not know what you're getting yourself into before starting a team on your own (which can happen way too early at the moment). Earning money seems a bit imbalanced, since streaming is way too lucrative right now (in fact, more lucrative than being a Pro Gamer).All this is to be expected of a game in Early Access and I do imagine a lot of this (if not all) will see itself being adressed later in development but I can only rate the game for what it is now. The current meta of the game is way too impetuous, as very little is explained.I can't comment on the frequency of updates just yet. However, the lack of feedback is a common theme inside and around the game, since the developers of Pro Gamer Manager could communicate with their current fanbase a lot more. As a player you are pretty much left in the dark about the progress of the game. So far, patches were posted (the last one was around two months ago at the time of writing this) in the News section but you get no progress reports.Updates in the form of blog-like posts would be nice, maybe bi-weekly in order to actually know what they are working on as well as confirming they actually are working on the game. This will give players confidence and increase the amount of recommendations.A beta-branch might even help with bugtesting and getting feedback. The Store page reads:"Pro Gamer Manager is currently under development, but releases regular updates. We are actively working hard on fixing bugs and adding new features and content. Early Access will help us to get feedback and suggestions right away and continuously improve the game until final release. Check back to see what each new update brings[...]Community feedback helps us prioritize our long list of planned features and focus on fixing the worst bugs and issues. Early Access Review
								I can't recommend this game. As much as I want to like it, because I like the idea. But the game basically is just rng slapped on rng, slapped on rng, without any possibility for the player to influence anything. Pro/Cons list at the bottom of the review.You are given the feeling in the beginning that your decisions matter and the more you play, the more you realise that they don't. Not the slightest bit. And even if the game actually considers your choices and bases the rng on it, your choices still don't matter. There is absolutely no feedback why something worked and why something didn't work. If you play the FOBA part of the game or the FPS part of the game makes no difference, it's the same thing just with a different name and different pictures put onto it.In the FOBA career part you get to choose between 5 classes of champions which are divided into 3 categories themselves and thats about all the information the game gives you. If you choose to play the role of an ADC you have champions divided into chaser, burst and utility. While it might be self explanatory where those might have their strengths and weaknesses it does not matter which you pick. Regardless of the tactic, you might be doing extremely well or extremely bad. I've had winning streaks with miserable rated champions (which is another part of faking your influence towards the rng) and losing streaks with SS (which is the highest rated). I tried choosing tactics that made sense with the little information thats given to me and just to check, I tried doing the opposite a while. No difference.In the management part, it is basically the same. You hire players and they win you games in the lower leagues because they level up really fast and dominate the other teams, but once you get to the tournaments, even with the highest stats on your gamers, it is back to rolling the dice and you don't even get the 50:50 chance you had in the career part. And again tactics don't matter.The forum is full of unanswered questions about mechanics. They announced to leave early access on 29th of April, about a week from now, and it still has bugs which are just horrible. - If you start a new game, you have your player stats from the previous game but your skill level is calculated as if you were a new player which leads to the problem that you can't get any better if you maxed your skills in the previous game (but actually why should one care about it, since stats are an illusion just like choices).- you can unlock different topics to choose from when streaming (one of the ways to earn cash). I unlocked them and they disappeared on me later in the game and I'm stuck with only two topics to choose from (in both saves I played)- my team display got bugged at some point which led to me not being on the team anymore even after moving to a different team, my name just won't show up and since then I wasn't allowed to participate in any team event (not even as spectator, which is one of the options when there are such events)- the most recent one (which led to me writing this review). I was ranked 4th, won a game, and now im ranked -27. It really looks like the devs didn't even think people would play their game long enough to get to that point.Very disappointing.Pros:- the ideaCons:- bugs (the game is leaving early access in a week and still has game breaking bugs)- no feedback on what your tactic/role/champion choices actually do (I'm fairly certain they don't do anything)- there is no strategy involved whatsoever, not from an economic point of view, nor from a tactic/team building point of view.Unfortunately it is a very shallow game and to make it even worse everything has a small clock ticking up. Thats so extensive that I would have gotten to the part where I am in the game in 2-3 hours (or less) if it wasn't there, compared to the close to 15 hours playtime I am at right now.If you want a simulation other than complete rng in an esports environment don't buy it.

								After reading the reviews for this game, I was a bit worried about purchasing it. But, seeing as it was on sale, I decided to give it a shot, and I have to say, it was well worth it. I found myself mindlessly playing this game for hours on end. It is not without its issues, however.This game is about as close to the definition of simulation as you can get. If you are looking for a comparison, this game is very similar in design to "Game Dev Tycoon". You start out as a small, unskilled player of a game called FOBA (based of MOBAs such as LoL or Dota). As you play, you slowly get better at different champions, and can even start to make money off of your playing, but the real game starts once you create your own professional team.But that does come with a few side effects. As of now, the game has no real tutorial (although I am sure this will be added in the future). After spending about an hour and a half learning exactly how to play and mastering the little details, it was a bit annoying to suddenly start playing what is essentially an entirely different game. The solo play to team play mechanics are pretty much entirely different, but hey, you get two games for the price of one.The bulk of the game comes down to slowly moving up the competetive ranks with your team.You expand your office, hire new team members, and gain a fan base. My favorite part about the whole game is the team system. You can change exactly what each member on your team does in a game, and you can even set specific metas you are playing by.The only real problem I have with the game is its lack of feedback. At the end of a match, you get a few small tips about how you lost and a statement from a specatator, but these generally have to do with specific elemtents from FOBA, not anything you can actually effect. And this is the only feedback you get. When I make a decision to make a certain play or have one of my teammembers slightly change their playstyle and lose, I have no idea what caused the loss. It basically comes down to trial and error. Many people have said that winning/losing is completely random, but I do not believe that is true. There are just a large amount of factors that come into play. The stats of your team, your meta, team matchups, team synerger, morale, roles, the meta you are playing. With all of this, it is easy to lose track of what you need to work on. I think a specific stats page after each game that gives you some explanation as to what you can fix would really help.Overall, this is a fun game. It has a few annoying bugs, and a couple flaws here and there, but that doesn't really hinder the concept at all, or in anyway break the game. After all, the game is still in early access, and only came out a few days ago for that matter. If you are into MOBAs, this game is a must have. Just wait a bit if you are worried about anything I mentioned.

								As of 2/4/16, I have beaten the game and probably have some sort of plausable opinion considering that I play MOBAs on a regular basis to say this game is playable yet boring and doesn't simulate pro/casual player.I want to preface this with a message to the developers:STOP TRYING TO ADD NEW THINGS TO DIVERSIFY THE GAME AND START ADDING CORE MECHANICS TO WHAT YOU ALREADY HAVE. THE GAME IS BROKEN AND AN UNENJOYABLE FIRST EXPERIENCE.Onto the review.Your champion/character picks don't mean anything since their role means nothing, their position in the meta or OP Chart means nothing since it doesn't impact matches, and you can't dictate anything in the middle of the game. The Pick/Ban phase is useless, since you chose your character prior to the actual select (which nobody would do), and you can't improvise mid game to change playstyle. You do nothing for your character, you can't see what's going on, you can't post-analyze the match, and you can't give your person/character an area to work on. Champion mastery is also irrelevant. When I select a character who I have never touched before I have a higher winrate than a champion I have spent most of 4 hours working on.The FPS category is irrelevant since there's literally nothing there. Just some icons.Managing a team was fun until your players started underperforming for no reason, with no statistical proof of lack of ability to play the game, and you can't negotiate or haggle using contracts with players so you're often stuck with a level 2 mid laner in a team where everyone is level 80+. (I know they don't have levels, it's just easier to explain using such lingo).My biggest pet peeve is that the character mean nothing. Literally nothing, they're just icons with smaller icons in the top left corner. They don't have pros, cons, weaknesses early, weakness late, magic or physical damage reference, and in general mean nothing. This means that you can't really help your "team" when they ask you for a single target burster. What? Does this fairy thing do burst damage, aoe damage, or does this dragon heal? There is no explanation to characters.TL;DR This game is a shell and technically shouldn't be an early access game since this isn't a game right now. But I very much like the concept and it would be awesome to manage a character that you love and want to improve and win the FOBA (whatever that stands for) world championships.

Early Access Review
								Hello, IHazMagics here and I wanted to talk about a recent game added to Steam. Pro Gamer Manager. Wherein you take the control of a Pro Gamer wannabe with grand aspirations. What I’m going to talk about is a few reasons you should buy the game, and a few reasons you probably shouldn’t. Please note, I don’t have an affiliation with the developer Millenway Studios, this is all from personal experience from game time I’ve had after release which, as of recording is about a day. There may be some words, or terminology that require understanding of MOBA’s in general, if you don’t have that understanding please, ask me to clarify, and I’d be happy to do so.So first off, the game is reminiscent for those that have played a game dev type game. It’s $9.74 USD currently. The first mark I’d put against the game is there’s not really a steam community as of yet. This isn’t a massive mark against the game as it could grow with time and be something that gets larger. However, there’s a very distinct lack of presence from the development team in the Steam forums. That’s something I’d like to see change.Ok, the premise of the game. I personally play a lot of League, but this game will appeal to you regardless of MOBA, although it’s very clearly marketed towards League players. You start as a casual player and seem to gain fans very quickly, while I accept this is intended, it does feel somewhat strange. Personal preference. Moving on. Minor add, lots of spelling mistakes, but it’s a foreign company, so I’d take that with a grain of salt.The first bug I encountered, is the incredibly lackluster menu. The tablet system that explains parts of the game (does it?) and gives you random announcements seems like an ill thought of overlay that doesn’t add anything and instead clutters the screen (which you can still access the base menu while in).Eventually, you’ll come to researching comfort picks. Which is nice. However, if you research the same champion again, instead of adding extra points into understanding an existing comfort pick, it simply creates another entry for the same champion. On top of that, not only does it create a fresh champion, it doesn’t have the same level of played experience. Which is supremely disappointing.Another bug I’ve encountered is also to do with comfort picks. Once you pick your 6th champion as a comfort pick. Selecting them in any game since, will have you selecting your 5th comfort pick. To experiment, I selected a 7th comfort pick champ, and it still picked the 5th.The options menu is completely barren, by which I mean it doesn’t exist. Want to mute your game? Sorry pal, not gonna happen. You have a very sub standard amount of options when you open the game (restricted to what resolution, whether it’s windowed or not, and what monitor it’s displayed on).After playing more and creating a random e-sports league you lose a lot of your individual identity. So I feel it should be clear whether you’re creating a team to be a part of, or creating a team to be the coach of.Basically, after playing the game, I don’t feel as if I have any agency, or any control over my pro gamer path. I’m just doing things, as I see them and if I have enough research then yep, I’m gonna do that. However, the effects of said research aren’t apparent beyond showing up in a profile and certainly aren’t explained through any tutorial.Which leads me to the last thing. A tutorial… Where is it? This game expects you to understand what’s going on straight from the get go, and if you don’t…. Well it doesn’t actually matter because you’ll still get fans anyway. Any of the choices in game don’t seem to have ANY impact long term, where they really should.As it stands right now, if what I’ve said interests you enough to support the dev team, please do so. If however, what I’ve said has made you consider where you spend your money, I think you are making a smart choice, and when the dev’s decide to make the game both A) true to the experience and B) work, then it will be a good game.
